facts.text: Writ Petition Nos. 201 to 203 of 1963 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by the petitioners for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Original Jurisdiction Writ Petition Nos. 201 to 203 of 1963. Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution for the en- forcement of the fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitioners are a partnership firm, dealers in skins, carrying on business at Shenbakkam, Vellore, North Arcot District in the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are dealers in skin, carrying on business at Shenbakkam, Vellore, North Arcot District. in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Petitioners purchase raw skins from places both within and outside the State of Madras, tan the same and sell them through their agents in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: They purchase raw skins from places both within and outside the State of Madras, tan the same and sell them through their agents in Madras.

facts.text: Petitioners assessed to sales-tax under Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939 and r.16(2)(ii) on turnover of hides and skins purchased untanned outside the State but tanned within the State for years 1955-56, 1956-57, 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: They were assessed to a certain amount of sales-tax, in accordance with the provisions of the Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939  Madras Act IX of 1939  and r.16 2  ii  of the rules...

facts.text: Tax assessed at 3 pies per rupee on the price of tanned hides and skins for 1955-56 and 1956-57, and at 2 per cent on turnover for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: The tax was assessed at 3 pies per rupee on the price of tanned hides and skins for the years 1955-56 and 1956-57 and at the rate of 2 per cent on the turnover for the year 1957-58.

facts.text: Petitioners filed writ petition No. 148 of 1959 challenging assessment for 1957-58, allowed by Supreme Court on November 22, 1962 in Firm Mehtab Majid & Co. v. State of Madras holding r.16(2) invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners then filed writ petition No. 148 of 1959 in this Court against the assessment of tax for the year 1957-58. This Court allowed it as it had held on November 22, 1962 in Firm Mehtab Majid...

facts.text: Writ petitions Nos. 43 and 44 of 1963 filed by M. J. Jamal Mohideen Co. on March 5, 1963 challenging validity of r.16(1).

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, the validity of r. 16 1  of the rules was challenged in this Court in writ petitions Nos. 43 and 44 of 1963 by M. J. Jamal Mohideen Co. Those writs were filed on March 5, 1963...

facts.text: Governor of Madras promulgated Madras Ordinance No. 3 of 1963 on June 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On June 10, 1963, the Governor of Madras promulgated Madras Ordinance No. 3 of 1963.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras on July 12, 1963 set aside petitioners' assessments for 1955-56 and 1956-57 and remanded for reassessment per s.2(3) of Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: On July 12, 1963, the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras dealt with the appeals of the petitioners against the assessment for the year 1955-56 and 1956-57...

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Special Provisions Act, 1963 (Act No. 11 of 1963) received assent of Governor on August 28, 1963, deemed in force from June 10, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On. August 28, 1963, the Act received the assent of the Governor. Sub-s. 2  of s. I provided that the Act would be deemed to have companye into force on June 10, 1963.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge s.2 of the Act as ultra vires Constitution, violating Arts. 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31, 286(2), 301, 304.

anchor.surface_text: These are three petitions under art. 32 by the petitioners... praying fora declaration that s. 2 of the Madras General Sales Tax Special Provisions  Act, 1963  Act No. 11 of 1963...

facts.text: Persons purchasing raw hides/skins in State paid 3 pies per rupee, no further tax on tanned sales; petitioners pay 2% on last purchase price of imported untanned, higher tax.

anchor.surface_text: Persons who had purchased raw hides and skins in the State of Madras in the years 1955-56 and 1956-57 paid sales tax at 3 pies per rupee...

facts.text: Court holds s.2(1) of Act has same effect as r.16(2), discriminatory and invalid per Mehtab case.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the first companytention for the peti- tioners is sound. The effect of sub-section  1  of s.2 of the Act is the same as was the effect of sub-rule  2  of r.16...

facts.text: Discrimination due to higher effective tax rate on imported tanned hides/skins (2%) vs local raw (3 pies/rupee = ~1.19%) up to August 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Such a discri- mination would affect the taxation up to the 1st of August 1957 when the rate of tax on the sale of raw hides and skins was raised to 2 per cent...

facts.text: Raw hides/skins and dressed hides/skins are different commodities commercially.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that raw hides and skins and dressed hides and skins companystitute different companymodities of merchandise...

facts.text: r.16(1) did not become invalid when r.16(2) held invalid in Mehtab case.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that sub-rule  1  of r.16 did number become invalid on this Courts declaring sub-rule  2  of that rule invalid in Mehtabs Case 1 .

facts.text: Hides and skins declared essential goods by Parliament under Act 52 of 1952, effective 1955-04-01 to 1956-09-11.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament had by The Essential Goods  Declaration Regulation of Tax on Sale or Purchase  Act 52 of 1952 declared hides and skins essential... between 1-4-1955 and 11-9-1956...

facts.text: State legislature competent to enact s.2(1) as Art.286(3) did not apply post-amendment.

anchor.surface_text: By August 28, 1963, when the Act was enacted by the Madras Legislature, Art. 286 3  had been amended and Act Lll of 1952 had also been repealed...

facts.text: s.2(1) held void in its entirety as void for initial period.

anchor.surface_text: The subsection being void in its provisions with respect to a certain initial period, we cannot change the provision... We have therefore to hold that sub-s. 1  of s. 2 void...

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 7, 1964 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL J.

anchor.surface_text: May 7, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL J.

facts.text: Rate of tax on raw hides/skins raised to 2% from August 1, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Such a discri- mination would affect the taxation up to the 1st of August 1957 when the rate of tax on the sale of raw hides and skins was raised to 2 per cent of the sale price.

facts.text: Petitioners' earlier contentions on r.16 violating Art.304 negatived by Sales Tax Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners challenged earlier the validity of r. 16 on the ground that it companytravened Art. 304 of the Constitution. Their companytentions were negatived by the Sales Tax Authorites.

anchor.surface_text: We are inclined to the view that they form dif- ferent categories. Hides and skins in the untanned companydition are undoubtedly different as articles of merchandise than tanned hides and skins.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that remains for companysideration is whether the State legislature was companypetent to enact the provisions of sub-section  1  of s. 2 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Act is affected by Articles 301 to 304 of the Constitution despite its retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued for the State that the Act is number affected by the provisions of Arts. 301 to 304 of the Constitution as they affect the legislative power with respect to Acts to operate in the future and number the power to enact Acts which would operate in the past.

issues.text: Whether s.2 of the Act violates Articles 19(1)(f) and (g), 31, 286(2), 301 and 304 apart from Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It is the validity of s. 2 of the Act that is challenged in these petitions, on the ground that it violates the provisions of Arts. 14, 19 i   f  and  g , 31, 286 2 , 301 and 304 of the Constitution for the following reasons-

arguments.claim: s.2(1) of the Act discriminates under Art.14 against petitioners who pay higher tax (2% on imported untanned purchase price) compared to local purchasers who paid 3 pies per rupee on raw hides/skins and no further tax on tanned sales

anchor.surface_text: Persons who had purchased raw hides and skins in the State of Madras in the years 1955-56 and 1956-57 paid sales tax at 3 pies per rupee and paid numberfurther tax when those hides, after being tanned, were sold. The petitioners having purchased raw hides and skins from outside the State, did number at the time pay tax at that rate on the purchase price of the raw hides and skins but were number liable, under the impugned provision, to pay tax at the rate of 2 per cent of the amount for which such hides and skins were last purchased in untanned companydition. Thus the petitioners would pay a higher tax than what was paid by the seller of dressed hides and skins purchased in the State in the raw companydition and then tanned and sold and that therefore s. 2 1  discriminates against imported untanned hides and skins.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cannot be taxed under sub-section  1   of s.2 of the Act. The next question is whether sub-rule  1  of r.16 be came invalid when this Court declared s

arguments.court_reasoning: Effect same as invalid r.16(2); discriminatory due to higher effective rate until Aug 1 1957 (2% vs ~1.19%)

arguments.claim: s.2(1) discriminates under Art.14 between local merchant selling locally dressed hides/skins (taxed on raw) and first seller in State who purchased dressed hides/skins outside (no untanned purchase, so not liable under s.2(1))

anchor.surface_text: In the case of sale of dressed hides and skins, s. 2 i  levies a tax at the rate of 2 per cent of the amount for which hides and skins in the untanned companydition were last purchased by a dealer himself outside the State. S. 2  i  creates discrimination between the case of a local mer- chant,selling locally dressed hides and skins and the case where the dealer who is the first seller in the State and who purchased only dressed hides and skins outside the State and then sold them in the State for in his case be had number purchased such hides and skins in the untanned companydition and has therefore number become liable to be assessed under s. 2 1

arguments.claim: No tax leviable on sales 1955-1956 without President's assent under Art.286(3) as hides/skins declared essential by Act 52/1952

anchor.surface_text: Parliament had by The Essential Goods  Declaration Regulation of Tax on Sale or Purchase  Act 52 of 1952 declared hides and skins essential for the life of the company- munity. The Act provided for taxation on the sale of hides and skins during the period such declaration was in. force, i.e., between 1-4-1955 and 11-9-1956 and therefore required the assent of the President, in view of Art. 286 3  of the Constitution as it stood prior to its repeal in Sep- tember, 1965. As numbersuch assent had been received, the Act cannot affect the sales prior to September 11, 1956 and so numbertax can be levied in respect of those sales.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e or purchase of goods which were goods declared essential for the of the, companymissioner. We do number see why such a fetter be placed on the legis

arguments.court_reasoning: Competence judged at time of enactment (1963); Art.286(3) amended, Act 52 repealed; retrospective operation valid without assent

anchor.surface_text: Rule 16 1  became invalid when this Court held r.16 2  invalid. Rule 16 1  has number been revived by the new Act. arguments.claim: s.2(1) void in entirety as discriminatory for initial period (pre-Aug 1957); cannot sever/rewrite

anchor.surface_text: The subsection being void in its provisions with respect to a certain initial period, we cannot change the provision... We have therefore to hold that sub-s. 1  of s. 2 void...

holdings.text: The effect of sub-section (1) of s.2 of the Act is the same as was the effect of sub-rule (2) of r.16 of the Turnover and Assessment Rules, 1939, and which was held to be invalid by this Court in Mehtab's Case. The present rule therefore is discriminatory and invalid for the same reasons which led this Court to hold sub-rule (2) of r. 16 invalid in Mehtab's Case.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the first contention for the peti- tioners is sound. The effect of sub-section  1  of s.2 of the Act is the same as was the effect of sub-rule  2  of r.16 of the Turnover and Assessment Rules, 1939, and which was held to be invalid by this Court in Mehtabs Case 1 . The present rule therefore is discriminatory and invalid for the same reasons which led this Court to hold sub-rule  2  of r. 16 invalid in Mehtabs Case 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent from Mehtab case where r.16(2) held discriminatory; s.2(1) exempts locally taxed raw but taxes imported untanned at higher effective rate.

holdings.text: The second contention has no force. There is nothing in sub-section (1) of s.2 of the Act to suggest that the seller of the tanned hides and skins in the State, should himself be the purchaser of those hides and skins in the raw condition from outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: The second contention has no force. There is nothing in sub-section  1  of s.2 of the Act to suggest that the seller of the tanned hides and skins in the State, should himself be the purchaser of those hides and skins in the raw condition from outside the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: s.2(1) does not require seller to be untanned purchaser; tax assessable on importer of tanned via estimation if needed.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that raw hides and skins and dressed hides and skins constitute different commodities of merchandise and they could therefore be treated as different goods for the purposes of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that raw hides and skins and dressed hides and skins constitute different commodities of merchandise and they could therefore be treated as different goods for the purposes of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tanning is manufacturing process changing commodity; supported by precedents, encyclopedia, statutes treating separately.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that sub-rule (1) of r.16 did not become invalid on this Court's declaring sub-rule (2) of that rule invalid in Mehtab's Case.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that sub-rule  1  of r.16 did not become invalid on this Courts declaring sub-rule  2  of that rule invalid in Mehtabs Case 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Severability: different commodities mean separate series of sales; invalidity of r.16(2) does not affect r.16(1).

holdings.text: The State legislature was competent to enact the provisions of sub-section (1) of s. 2 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The only question that remains for consideration is whether the State legislature was competent to enact the provisions of sub-section  1  of s. 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Competence judged at enactment time (1963): Art.286(3) amended, Essential Goods Act repealed; retrospective valid without assent.

holdings.text: There is no force in this contention. The tax is imposed on the sale which took place within the State.

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in this contention. The tax is imposed on the sale which took place within the State. The State legislature is competent to impose such a tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intra-state sale; import does not convert to inter-state trade; distinguishes precedent.

holdings.text: We do not consider the contention sound. The Act makes provision for a period subsequent to the commencement of the Constitution and therefore is to be subject to the provisions of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider the contention sound. The Act makes provision for a period subsequent to the commencement of the Constitution and therefore is to be subject to the provisions of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective Act covering post-Constitution period subject to Arts.301-304.

holdings.text: We therefore hold that sub-section (1) of s. 2 of the Act discriminates against imported hides and skins which were sold up to the 1st of August 1957... The subsection being void in its provisions with respect to a certain initial period, we cannot change the provision... We have therefore to hold that sub-s. (1) of s. 2 void... In view of the provisions of sub-section (1) of s. 2 being invalid the other provisions of that section become unenforceable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Discrimination partial but void in toto as cannot sever/rewrite; other provisions unenforceable.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the first contention for the peti- tioners is sound. The effect of sub-section  1  of s.2 of the Act is the same as was the effect of sub-rule  2  of r.16 of the Turnover and Assessment Rules, 1939, and which was held to be invalid by this Court in Mehtabs Case 1 . The present rule therefore is discriminatory and invalid for the same reasons which led this Court to hold sub-rule  2  of r. 16 invalid in Mehtabs Case 1 .
We have therefore to hold that sub-s. 1 of s. 2 void accordingly hold so. In view of the provisions of sub-section 1 of s. 2 being invalid the other provisions of that section become unenforceable.
